The chance of a lethal confrontation between the People’s Republic of China and any of the other countries listed does not appear to be significantly high in the next 24 days. Any type of incident would stem from tensions regarding differing claims to the South China Sea.

As China continues to assert its claim to areas within the 9-dash line in the South China Sea, the pressure is mounting on its southern neighbors. China projects power through its artificial islands that serve as staging bases for aircraft, warships, and maritime vessels. For a country like Malaysia who is conducting resource exploration in disputed waters, China's expansion represents a direct challenge to their territorial claims. Other tensions have manifested with Indonesia deploying fighter jets and naval ships to deter Chinese fishing in its waters and Chinese vessels sake a Vietnamese fishing boat in vicinity of the Paracel Islands. China's strategy is to slowly wear down the opposition to its territorial claims (Wescott & Lendon, 2020). Since the 1970s, Southeast Asian states have squabbled over the territorial claims to land masses and navigation rights in the South China Sea. China leverages its nine-dash line claims to argue its claims to sovereignty, yet other nations such as the US argue, that freedom of navigation is not trumped by claims to economic exchange zones (EEZs). Washington has interests in maintaining freedom of navigation in the area and provides backing to countries such as the Philippines and Taiwan (CFR, 2021). China uses the US commitment to rules of engagement of the law of war to its advantage. Instead of deterring US warships with the military, China hires fishermen and other non-governmental vessels to harass its neighbors in the region. This strategy effectively avoids the prospect of conflict, offers Beijing plausible deniability, and great political risk of a neighboring country's ship fires on one of the vessels as it would appear an attack on innocent civilians (Gady, 2015). China values stability as a top priority. Making war with neighboring states would certainly destabilize the southeast Asian economies. Alternatively, China employs a long game of incremental aggression that rarely crosses the threshold of conflict that would warrant an escalation of force. The risk of lethal conflict as a result of defensive aggression from Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, and/or Vietnam is also unlikely. Although some leaders in Vietnam and Indonesia have attempted to confront Beijing on its incursions, these nations value stability as well and thus would prefer a diplomatic solution to armed conflict. China will not hesitate to retaliate against one of these nations if the US ceases to back them. If the US departs, then the chances for conflict increase as China will capitalize on the power vacuum left behind to secure its national interests in the Sea. Council of Foreign Relations. (2021, 05 March). Territorial Disputes in the South China Sea. https://www.cfr.org/global-conflict-tracker/conflict/territorial-disputes-south-china-sea

Considering the U.S.’s ramping up of operations in the South China Sea (SCS) since President Biden took office (Lendon, 2021), there would be more likelihood of a China-U.S. confrontation as compared to a confrontation of China and the other nations who are claimants of the SCS. However, China passed a new Coast Guard Law on January 22, 2021, which “empowers the force to ‘take all necessary measures, including the use of weapons, when national sovereignty, sovereign rights, and jurisdiction are being illegally infringed upon by foreign organizations or individuals at sea’” (Philippines protests new China law as `verbal threat of war’, 2021). Considering the actions that China has already taken in the SCS, and the fact that it claims most of the SCS as being within its territory, this new law creates a much higher likelihood of China sparking conflict in the SCS against rivals including Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, and/or Vietnam. I gauge that the overall threat is low but probable within the timeframe of this prediction, however long-term is a whole nother story.

The territorial disputes in the South China Sea involve the states of China, the Philippines, Brunei, Malaysia, and Vietnam. The Spratly and Paracel Islands, specifically, are the source of increasing contention. China’s island-building and land reclamation efforts based on claims of historical sovereignty encroach on the territorial islands and waters of these South Asian states. Indonesia and Singapore assert they are non-claimants in the South China Sea disputes. Confrontations stemming from these disputes have involved police/military forces of the respective country’s sovereign waters and the fishing vessels of other claimants who entered the waters. The coast guards of various claimants have encountered each other and used intimidation tactics as well . However, there has not been a lethal confrontation between the respective militia/military forces/law enforcement of the claimants yet. There is a factor that may diminish the possibility of a future lethal confrontation.

The likelihood of a lethal confrontation between the national military forces, militia, and/or law enforcement personnel of the People's Republic of China and those of Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, and/or Vietnam before 1 April 2021 is extremely low based off current China-ASEAN relations and recent history. In September 2020, Chinese State Councilor and Foreign Minister Wang Yi visited Myanmar, Indonesia, Brunei, and the Philippines in an effort to deepen mutual trust and promote cooperation, with Yi emphasizing that China-ASEAN relations is one of his top priorities. China and ASEAN countries have cooperated closely in a joint pandemic response, working together to develop and distribute vaccines, indicating non-hostile relations. However, over the past year, tensions have risen out of China’s aggressive behavior in the South China Sea, with Malaysia, Vietnam, and the Philippines (along with a handful of Western countries) releasing statements calling on states to follow the rule of international law. In 2020, China increased tensions between itself and Vietnam, Malaysia, and the Philippines as the Chinese Coast Guard sank a Vietnamese fishing boat (no one was injured), a Chinese ship entered contested waters off Malaysia, and a Chinese warship aimed its weapons control radar at a Philippine naval vessel; however, no direct military conflict occurred. It is well-known that China, Vietnam, Taiwan, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Brunei are locked in an overlapping series of maritime and territorial disputes, and though tensions between China and these countries wax and wane, it seems as if China is currently focused on strengthening diplomatic relations with ASEAN countries and keeping an eye on Western powers, especially the US, who send naval assets through the South China Sea region. Additionally, China has launched a month of military exercises and closed off around 80 square kilometers in Chinese waters for the month of March, so it is likely that military attention (at least the navy) will be diverting its attention to these exercises. There is a very low likelihood of a lethal military confrontation in the next month; however, with tensions being so high, it is possible that a ship or submarine in the wrong area or a trade dispute could escalate into a lethal military conflict, which is why I am giving a 5% likelihood of occurrence.

According to the Council on Foreign Relations Global Conflict tracker, “Tensions between China and both the Philippines and Vietnam have recently cooled, even as China increased its military activity in the South China Sea by conducting a series of naval maneuvers and exercises in March and April 2018.” With China conducting military exercises in the South China Sea for the entire month of March in a designated five-kilometer radius, as well as the presence of U.S. and French naval military vessels, China’s neighbors will likely be wary to increase tensions with the heavily preoccupied People’s Liberation Army Navy. Since Germany is also planning to send a warship through the area, the Chinese government will likely sense increasing pressure from NATO powers and focus their attention on these issues rather than squabbles with the countries in question. Any lethal engagements with neighboring nations in the South China Sea littoral region would likely only fuel further western pressure against China and not work to the advantage of the Chinese Communist Party, thus I suspect it is almost certain China will limit military action to their usual posturing against western naval vessels in the area. Based on this, I am forecasting a 99% chance there will be no lethal confrontations between China and Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, and/or Vietnam prior to the end of their military exercises concluding at the end of this month. If Chinese military activity in the South China Sea does not decrease following the conclusion of this exercise, it may be indicative of intentions to conduct territorial enforcement operations which could lead to lethal confrontations like those seen from Russia in the Eastern European region, however, this is not within the bounds of this question or response and would require further research for a more informed analysis. As a result, I am only assigning a 1% chance to the question posed.
